<misra_rule>
MISRA C 2023 Rule 8.13 is: A pointer should point to a const-qualified type whenever possible.

</misra_rule>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- is_rule_violated: whether the rule is violated or not (true/false),
- scenario: a specific violation scenario.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of metal_uio_dev_close:
```c
static void metal_uio_dev_close(struct linux_bus *lbus,
				struct linux_device *ldev)
{
	(void)lbus;
	unsigned int i;

	for (i = 0; i < ldev->device.num_regions; i++) {
		metal_unmap(ldev->device.regions[i].virt,
			    ldev->device.regions[i].size);
	}
	if (ldev->override) {
		sysfs_write_attribute(ldev->override, "", 1);
		ldev->override = NULL;
	}
	if (ldev->sdev) {
		sysfs_close_device(ldev->sdev);
		ldev->sdev = NULL;
	}
	if (ldev->fd >= 0) {
		close(ldev->fd);
	}
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are close to the target function metal_uio_dev_close:
struct linux_device {
	struct metal_device		device;
	char				dev_name[PATH_MAX];
	char				dev_path[PATH_MAX];
	char				cls_path[PATH_MAX];
	metal_phys_addr_t		region_phys[METAL_MAX_DEVICE_REGIONS];
	struct linux_driver		*ldrv;
	struct sysfs_device		*sdev;
	struct sysfs_attribute		*override;
	int				fd;
}
</additional code>
<target_code>
Here is the code fragment that you need to analyze:
```c
static void metal_uio_dev_close(struct linux_bus *lbus,
				struct linux_device *ldev)
```
Focus on the above code fragment and judge whether it violates the rule 8.13 or not.
</target_code>
scenario: No violation: the function modifies members of the object pointed to by ldev (assigns ldev->override = NULL, ldev->sdev = NULL and examines ldev->fd), so ldev must not be const. The unused lbus parameter could in theory be const, but its non-const form may be required by the function signature or callback interface. Therefore Rule 8.13 is not violated in this code.
